metadata.title: W3Schools.com
metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: Python Strings
Strings
Strings in python are surrounded by either single quotation marks, or double quotation marks.
content.html: Strings in python are surrounded by either single quotation marks, or double quotation marks.

content.text: 'hello' is the same as "hello" .
content.html: 'hello' is the same as "hello".

content.text: You can display a string literal with the print() function:
content.html: You can display a string literal with the print() function:

content.code_html:
print("Hello")
print('Hello')

content.text: Quotes Inside Quotes
You can use quotes inside a string, as long as they don't match the quotes surrounding the string:
content.html: You can use quotes inside a string, as long as they don't match the quotes surrounding the string:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
print("It's alright")
print("He is called 'Johnny'")
print('He is called "Johnny"')

content.code:
print("It's alright")
print("He is called 'Johnny'")
print('He is called "Johnny"')

syntax_highlighting.text:
print("It's alright")
print("He is called 'Johnny'")
print('He is called "Johnny"')

content.code_html:
print("It's alright")
print("He is called 'Johnny'")
print('He is called "Johnny"')

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
print("It's alright")
print("He is called 'Johnny'")
print('He is called "Johnny"')

content.text: Assign String to a Variable
Assigning a string to a variable is done with the variable name followed by an equal sign and the string:
content.html: Assigning a string to a variable is done with the variable name followed by an equal sign and the string:

content.code_html:
a = "Hello"
print(a)

content.text: Multiline Strings
You can assign a multiline string to a variable by using three quotes:
content.html: You can assign a multiline string to a variable by using three quotes:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
a = """Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet,consectetur adipiscing elit,sed do 
  eiusmod tempor incididuntut labore et dolore magna aliqua."""print(a)

"Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet,consectetur adipiscing elit,sed do 
  eiusmod tempor incididuntut labore et dolore magna aliqua."

content.html: Or three single quotes:

content.text: Note: in the result, the line breaks are inserted at the same position as in the code.
content.html: Note: in the result, the line breaks are inserted at the same position as in the code.

content.text: Strings are Arrays
Like many other popular programming languages, strings in Python are arrays of bytes representing unicode characters.
content.html: Like many other popular programming languages, strings in Python are arrays of bytes representing unicode characters.

content.text: However, Python does not have a character data type, a single character is simply a string with a length of 1.
content.html: However, Python does not have a character data type, a single character is simply a string with a length of 1.

content.text: Square brackets can be used to access elements of the string.
content.html: Square brackets can be used to access elements of the string.

content.code_html:
a = "Hello, World!"
print(a[1])

content.text: Looping Through a String
Since strings are arrays, we can loop through the characters in a string, with a for loop.
content.html: Since strings are arrays, we can loop through the characters in a string, with a for loop.

content.code_html:
for x in "banana":
  print(x)

content.text: Learn more about For Loops in our Python For Loops chapter.
content.html: Learn more about For Loops in our Python For Loops chapter.

content.text: String Length
To get the length of a string, use the len() function.
content.html: To get the length of a string, use the len() function.

content.code_html:
a = "Hello, World!"
print(len(a))

content.text: Check String
To check if a certain phrase or character is present in a string, we can use the keyword in .
content.html: To check if a certain phrase or character is present in a string, we can use the keyword in.

syntaxHighlighting.text: txt = "The best things in life are free!"print("free" in txt)
"The best things in life are free!"

content.code: txt = "The best things in life are free!"print("free" in txt)

syntax_highlighting.text: txt = "The best things in life are free!"print("free" in txt)
"The best things in life are free!"

content.code_html:
txt = "The best things in life are free!"
print("free" in txt)

syntax_highlighting_data.text: txt = "The best things in life are free!"print("free" in txt)
"The best things in life are free!"

content.text: Use it in an if statement:
content.html: Use it in an if statement:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
txt = "The best things in life are free!"if "free" in txt: 
print("Yes, 'free' is present.")
"The best things in life are free!"

txt = "The best things in life are free!"if "free" in txt:
print("Yes, 'free' is present.")

content.text: Learn more about If statements in our Python If...Else chapter.
content.html: Learn more about If statements in our Python If...Else chapter.

content.text: Check if NOT
To check if a certain phrase or character is NOT present in a string, we can use the keyword not in .
content.html: To check if a certain phrase or character is NOT present in a string, we can use the keyword not in.

syntaxHighlighting.text: txt = "The best things in life are free!"print("expensive" not in txt)
"The best things in life are free!"

content.code: txt = "The best things in life are free!"print("expensive" not in txt)

syntax_highlighting.text: txt = "The best things in life are free!"print("expensive" not in txt)
"The best things in life are free!"

content.code_html:
txt = "The best things in life are free!"
print("expensive" not in txt)

syntax_highlighting_data.text: txt = "The best things in life are free!"print("expensive" not in txt)
"The best things in life are free!"

content.text: Use it in an if statement:
content.html: Use it in an if statement:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
txt = "The best things in life are free!"if "expensive" not in txt: 
print("No, 'expensive' is NOT present.")
"The best things in life are free!"

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
What will be the result of the following code: x = 'Welcome' print(x[3])

x = 'Welcome'
